displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Of course, I always encourage you guys if it’s available to do the trial because you get a shot at new stuff, you know. I know it’s not a hundred percent shot but it’s better than, it’s not zero so. We’ll talk more Patient: Okay, Alright yeah lets. Doctor: in depth on that. That way you know the schedule, Patient: Right. Doctor: the potential side effects, you know, and you have to decide if it’s worth it for you but I appreciate both of you keeping an open mind which you have done so. Patient: Yes, I have, you know. Doctor: Yes, thank you for that. Patient: You’re the doctor. I’m never gonna deny that. Doctor: Yeah, thank you for coming back and just sort of, you know, they’re like do you want to come, I’m like no, it’s too complicated to have this conversation on the phone. I want them here so we have a plan. Plus, I was a little worried about your pain. Patient: Yeah, okay. I appreciate that. Doctor: Yeah, which is now kind of making me think that maybe, you know, the stuff in the bone is just sort of acting up and has really, we passed the biopsy sort of situation. I mean this should be better. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islande: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

displayed_text: Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure. Doctor: To take the edge off. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So that you can actually enjoy your life. Patient: Sure. Quality has been there. It hasn’t been compromised yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And I understand where you’re

Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I think that’s fair. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think that’s reasonable. It reasonable. Doctor: Are you just agreeing with me to agree with me? Patient: No, no, no, no, no, no. Really. Doctor: Am I making sense? Patient: No seriously it makes sense. Doctor: All right. The other thing I want to do- oh my gosh is the same person calling us. Family Member: I know, I thought the same thing Doctor: All right, what I want to do is um…does this make sense to you the stages of prostate cancer and where we are? Patient: Yes.Yes

Patient: Okay. Doctor: …than that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. But you need a driver and so you know we have to get, yeah. Patient: I don’t know if I get one by tomorrow. Doctor: You probably can’t and they probably can’t do it tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’d love for you to do it tomorrow, but the odds are we have to check your insurance and get the time slot and… Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: When are you supposed to take off again? Patient: Wednesday. As as I said to… Doctor: I know. You’ll…

Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Leave alone you know in any other place. Family Member: Sure. Doctor: Whatever we can do close to home we can, we do, but most of the stuff is not allowed. You know the FDA just regulates that pretty tightly. Family Member 2: Okay so I guess we’ll just stick with what we’re doing. Doctor: So I think uh, you know think about it. For now we’ve given you the pills but if you decide to come off based if today’s PSA is going higher regardless of the scans, that’s perfectly okay. Nobody is going to be mad at you. You’re allowed to make that decision. And uh… Patient: Yeah I… Doctor: I just - Give me a head’s up so I can talk to Dr. K____ and you know make that transition back. Patient: Uh huh. I see. Doctor: Just so he’s not shocked and you know he’s not panicking and calling me when you’re there in his office as to what happened. Patient: Ha-ha, yeah. Yeah. Family Member: So if his bone scan shows progression, are you gonna be in touch with him then?

Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we…

Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So there’s a little bit of progression there that maybe… Doctor: It’s a movement you know. Healthcare Professional: …we’ll do something different for you. Okay. Doctor: Yeah so I’m thinking we’re always trying to not be behind. Patient: Right, right.. Doctor: Like every single time when you started the first day I met you we’re always behind the cancer. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stuff happens and I’m reactive. Patient: Stop doctor, we’re not saying that word no more. Doctor: Sorry about that. We’re always behind the thing. Patient: The thing, yes.

Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before. Patient: Sure. Doctor: This will be the same at the left. If there’s any hint of any pain, we just do an x-ray to make sure there’s something that we got to do we’ll worry about it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You’re getting treated. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And it’s working.

Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: You know once we’re… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The good news is when I see this though it tells me it will die. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Because sometimes we give the chemo and it just keeps on going and you’re like what happened? Didn’t I just poison you? Patient: Thank you, Yeah thank you. Doctor: So it’s finally actually going in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you will need to continue on the prednisone also which I forgot to ask you are you still on that? Patient: I’m still taking it yeah. Doctor: Perfect so you know the job isn’t done, but once we get more chemo on board you should feel better. But also just pain medicine wise, so what are you taking? Anything right now?

Patient: We did, we did. Doctor: No, no, what did you have today? Yeah. Well, I, I think that’s also part of this is getting me and the radiation folks together ‘cuz I think we’re ordering redundant now. I mean, they ordered a test; I ordered a test. You know, we’re, we need to kind of Patient: Okay. Doctor: Get one test, one doctor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you probably didn’t need to have another PSA test this soon, but we got one. Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine. Doctor: ‘Cuz in this clinic, (laughs) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It’s automatic. Appointment. PSA. Appointment. So, that’s what they did, too. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Of course. It’s still the same? The PSA. Doctor: So. It’s, it’s not back yet.

Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. So, tend to see you on a Tuesday. Is everything clear? And, then we pick a day and you just go and get it. Patient: Alright. Doctor: And then that day, the people upstairs have cleared it for you. Your, uh, counts are okay. That your time is upstairs is shortened because - - Patient: I won’t have to wait for results. Doctor: Correct.

Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down. Doctor: You’re absolutely right. Yep. But I think you know whether you’re on this study or not as we talked about in the past, you, that pill is something that is a standard of care. Like I would give that whether you make it on this study or whether you choose to be on this study. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: So that’s the good part. Family Member: Now this has been approved? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. That one is approved. Healthcare Professional: The Xtandi, yes. Family Member: Yeah. You, you supply pill or do we have to use our insurance? Doctor: We supply the pills. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Um, hum. Doctor: Yeah same with uh the study is to see if a second pill helps this pill work better so if you’re in the group that gets the second pill, we provide that too. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Most people just get sleepy and want to take a nap and then they feel better but everyone’s different. Okay? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make a copy of this and then. Oh yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know, that’s not you and it kind of, you know, we were hoping with a little bit more time away from the Xtandi that that would have been you Patient: Right. Doctor: but that’s not the way you’re declaring yourself so, no, it won’t help. Patient: Okay. That’s no problem. Doctor: Yeah, we just need to move on to something a little bit more powerful. That is powerful in the right setting. You know, kind of like you’re almost like you have the flu and then I come around hey, did you want that flu shot, I’m kind of in the middle of it so no point whereas if this was a few months ago and it’s before flu season then it’s hey, it’s time for the flu shot. Okay, I’ll get it before I’m actually having the flu and the symptoms. Patient: That reminds me of another question.
